Award.AwardTitle: Multiscale computational methods in kinetic theory and optimal transport
Award.AbstractNarration:
Kinetic equations with multiple scales arise in diverse applications such as rarefied gas dynamics, plasma physics, semiconductors, and biology; they often introduce severe numerical challenges due to the stiffness that comes from the small scales. Optimal transport plays a fundamental role in image registration, video restoration, urban transport, kinetic theory and many others. However, numerical methods for it have not reached their full capacity to meet the most demanding practical applications. This project aims at both advancing the multiscale computational methods - particularly the asymptotic preserving (AP) schemes - in new prospects for kinetic equations including multi-stage and fractional asymptotic limit, and developing fast parallelizable algorithms for optimal transport via advanced optimization technique.

Specifically, the following topics will be investigated in this project: (1) theoretically study the AP schemes for semiconductor Boltzmann equation with two-scale collisions at a deeper depth and generalize them to implicit/high order schemes and to capture the hierarchy of macroscopic models; (2) extend the AP scheme for kinetic equation with fractional diffusion limit to a broader scope including anisotropic scattering, degenerate collision, and Levy-Fokker-Planck interaction (applications to nonclassical photon transport in clouds will be addressed); (3) develop efficient algorithms for optimal transport problems and conduct convergence analysis and apply it to practical problems especially for human crowd dynamics in panic situations. With increasing interest in multiscale kinetic equations and optimal transport, the computational methods developed here will impact beyond the particular applications in this proposal. The dynamics of electron transport in semiconductor devices are one of the main concerns in physics and engineering; the developed methods from this proposal will be equally applicable in a broader context such as gas discharges and multi-group radiative transfer. Nonclassical transport that leads to a fractional diffusion has attracted much attention in plasma physics and economy; it has now been applied in climate science to model the photon transport in clouds as well as in criminology to model the hotspots in residential burglaries. Optimal transport has become a useful tool in image processing, urban transport, computer vision and etc; the development of fast parallelizable algorithms will substantially advance these areas and the application in modeling human crowds is crucial for better preparation of safe mass events.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the support of this grant, the PI and her collaborators have developed new theories and numerical methods for multiscale kinetic theory, in both forward and inverse settings. 

In the forward setting, major efforts have been devoted to designing asymptotic preserving (AP) methods for multiscale kinetic equations, and  deploying the methods to study biological models. Specific outcomes include: 1) development of AP schemes for kinetic equations with fractional diffusion limit, which can be adopted in a wider contest to simulate and understand phenomena that cannot be described by classical Brownian motion, such as photon transport in clouds and light propagation in biological tissue; 2) development of front capturing schemes for nonlinear PDEs with free boundary limit. Evolution in physical or biological systems often involves interplay between convective or diffusive transport, and nonlinear interaction among the constituent "particles". When the nonlinearity becomes profound, a typical regime it resides in is the free boundary limit, which is extremely difficult to capture numerically. We have provided a rather general mechanism to deal with the strong nonlinearity in an efficient way, especially in capering the front dynamics. Consequently, this method has been applied to study the boundary propagation for tumor growth models; 3) design of AP schemes for nonlinear radiative transfer equation that has both good stability and scalability. It has hyperbolic CFL condition in the diffusive regime, and only need a scalar nonlinear solver local at each spatial point. So the method is very promising in practical applications.

In the inverse setting, we focused on optical tomography, which aims at reconstructing optical properties of  biological tissue by inserting near infra-red light into the tissue and measuring outgoing photon current at the boundaries. The movement of photons is modeled by the radiative transport equation (RTE). When multiple scales present, in the forward problem, diffusion equation is well acknowledged to be a good approximation to the RTE in certain scaling, whereas such theory is lacked for inverse problem. By analyzing the stability of the inverse problem, we first revealed a transition from the well-posed inverse transport problem to the ill-posed Calderon like problem. We also conducted numerical analysis for inverse RTE that leverages the singular decomposition analysis. These results will help in developing efficient numerical inversion methods that are of vital interest in applications such as cancer diagnosis and tumor detection.

The project also facilitated training graduate/undergraduate students and offering topic courses. The results of the research have been widely disseminated by journal publications, presentations in nation-wide and international gatherings, and organizing sessions at conferences.
